title: Curtains rise on four stage productions on South Plains
text:
Curtains rise on four stage productions on South Plains Theater Box Back | Next Lisa Kron (played by Savannah Cooper), left, introduces all of the participants of the 4th of July Parade in a scene from the drama "Well," which will be staged Friday through Sunday at the Texas Tech Maedgen Lab Theatre. The entrance is located on the west side of the Maedgen Theatre. Call 742-3603 for reservations. Back | Next Polly Browne (played by Jordan Sanders), right, falls in love with messenger boy Tony (Michael Peschell) in the musical "The Boy Friend," being staged Friday and Saturday at the McDonald Moody Auditorium on the Lubbock Christian University campus. 
“The Boy Friend” — 7:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday, McDonald Moody Auditorium on the Lubbock Christian University campus. 1953 British musical with music, lyrics and book by Sandy Wilson. Set in 1920s jazz age against the backdrop of French Riviera, story centers on English heiress Polly, who longs for a boyfriend. Stage direction by Laurie Doyle; Don Williams, technical director. Reserved seats $17.50 for the general public, and $10 for all students with valid IDs and children age 2 and older. 720-7429 or visit lcu.edu/tickets. 
Final performances. 
“The Good Doctor” — 7:30 p.m. Friday-Saturday, Harral Studio Theatre on the Plainview campus of Wayland Baptist University. Series of short plays by Neil Simon, inspired by the works of Russian writer Anton Chekhov. Directed by WBU alum Cory Norman. General admission seating $8 for the general public and $4 for WBU alumni. Students admitted free Thursday. (806) 291-1060. 
Final performances. 
“Well” — 8 p.m. Friday-Saturday, and 2 p.m. Sunday, Texas Tech Maedgen Laboratory Theatre (west entrance), 2812 18th St. between Boston and Flint avenues. Original drama written by Lisa Kron and directed by Amanda Espinoza. Explores dynamics of health, family and community with story of her mother’s extraordinary ability to heal a changing neighborhood, despite her inability to heal herself. Reserved seats $10 for the general public and $5 for all students with valid IDs. Free student rush tickets available on limited basis to Tech students. 742-3603. 
Final performances. 
“You Can’t Take It With You” — 8 p.m. Thursday, Texas Tech Maedgen Theatre, 2812 18th St. between Boston and Flint avenues. Comedy by Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman. Directed by Jonathan Marks; cast includes former theater students Jaston Williams, Richard Privitt, Kim Ansolabehere and Sylvia Ashby. Reserved seats $18 for general public and $5 for students with valid IDs; free student rush tickets available on limited basis to Tech students. 742-3603. 
Future performances: Oct. 9-11.
